data.text: A slothful man is compared to a stone that is defiled;
A slothful man is compared to the filth of a dunghill:
A father hath shame in having begotten an uninstructed son;
A prudent daughter shall inherit a husband of her own;
She that is bold bringeth shame upon father and husband;
Unseasonable discourse is as  music in mourning;
He that teacheth a fool is as  one that glueth a potsherd together;
He that discourseth to a fool is as  one discoursing to a man that slumbereth;
Verses 9 and 10 are omitted by the best authorities.
Weep for the dead, for light hath failed him;
Seven days are the days of  mourning for the dead;
Talk not much with a foolish man,
What shall be heavier than lead?
Sand, and salt, and a mass of iron, is easier to bear,
Timber girt and bound into a building shall not be loosed with shaking:
A heart settled upon a thoughtful understanding
Pales set on a high place will not stand against the wind:
He that pricketh the eye will make tears to fall;
Whoso casteth a stone at birds frayeth them away;
If thou hast drawn a sword against a friend, despair not;
If thou hast opened thy mouth against a friend, fear not;
Gain trust with thy neighbour in his poverty,
Before fire is the vapour and smoke of a furnace;
I will not be ashamed to shelter a friend;
And if any evil happen unto me because of him,
Who shall set a watch over my mouth,
